for infrastructure we have 21 geographic regions and across them we have 66
availability zones with 12 new availability zones coming online soon now interesting point about
the region's a lot of people think that a region is just a data center in other
words you can drop a pin on a map and that's an AWS region but that's a gross oversimplification each region consists
of at least two availability zones and in the case of the US East one region we
have six availability zones now an availability zone is often one or more
data centers and the availability zone architecture is very interesting because
availability zones are separated from each other in a given region by a meaningful amount of Geographic distance
such that they're resilient to natural disasters but they're also close enough
and we've networked them together with high-bandwidth low-latency networking
redundant networking such that you can deploy applications into regions that
take advantage of synchronous data replication across these availability zones and what that means is that you
can build applications with extremely high availability if you take advantage of this kind of architecture now on to
compute we have a service called ec2 it stands for elastic cloud compute this is
one of our oldest and those popular services on AWS with ec2 you can
allocate dozens of different virtual machine instance types each with customizable amounts of memory network
and storage for example if you have a workload that needs a lot of RAM you can
allocate an ec2 instance that's optimized for memory with 12 terabytes of RAM perfect if you're running
intensive in-memory workloads like the SA P HANA and memory database if you're
